Award.AbstractNarration:
Formal methods have made significant advances during the last decade, and now form the backbone
of formal assurance across hardware and software industries. Underlying many of these techniques
is the capability to effectively reason about system properties, often by describing the properties
as constraint satisfaction problems and delegating the reasoning to a constraint solver. The most
common constraint reasoning engines in use today are satisfiability (modulo theories) solvers (SAT
and SMT). As a rapidly developing field, there is a lack of highly trained users and researchers
that will sustain and further advance the field. The SAT/SMT summer school addresses this issue by
familiarizing young researchers with cutting-edge solver technologies and their applications.

The SAT/SMT summer school addresses this issue by familiarizing young researchers with cutting-edge solver
technologies and their applications. The lecturers at the school are world-renown experts, and the three day
gathering gives the students the opportunity to discuss the lecture topics, their own research, and the
challenges and future directions with these experts. The material is covered rigorously, with depth and breadth,
but at a pace appropriate for a student audience, making the school a unique place for disseminating new research
to the future users and researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boolean satisfiability (SAT) and satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) are two of the most prominent and effective paradigms for modelling and reasoning about systems in formal methods. Due to their effectiveness, SAT and SMT solvers are used as back-end reasoning engines in verification efforts across hardware and software industries. To familiarize young researchers with cutting-edge solver technologies and their applications, the SAT and SMT communities have initiated an annual SAT/SMT summer school. The school focuses on the foundations, architecture, and applications of satisfiability solvers. The lecturers at the school are world-renown experts in the field, and the three-day gathering gives the students a chance to discuss not only the lecture topics, but also their own research with these experts. As opposed to seminars and conferences, the topics at the school are covered at a pace appropriate for a student audience, making the school a unique place for disseminating important new research to the next generation of researchers. The school is also a meeting point for a community of young researchers that can support, encourage, and collaborate with one another. Every year, the summer school has had a significant positive impact, and the feedback from the students is overwhelmingly positive.

The 2014 edition of the SAT/SMT Summer School took place from July 10-12 in the Panhans hotel in Semmering, Austria. The program committee invited 12 speakers from both academia and industry. The program included lectures providing a systematic introduction to satisfiability and satisfiability modulo theories, lectures covering extensions such as parallel SAT solving and Craig interpolation, as well as lectures on applications such as security and verification. A detailed program, including abstracts and slides of all talks, is available on the web-page of the summer school at http://satsmt2014.forsyte.at/program.

The summer school was advertised widely and 83 participants were selected from 124 applicants (based on their resume, a letter of motivation, and a letter of recommendation). The school was attended by 81 participants, 12 lecturers, and 3 organizers. The audience was very international: the summer school was attended by participants from 31 different countries affiliated with institutions from 21 countries. 19% of the participants were female (this is in line with the percentage of female students in computer science). Three out of 12 lecturers were from industry, and the remaining 9 were affiliated with universities. Among the participants were 12 students and 1 post-doc from US-based universities, whose travel expenses were covered by travel grants provided by this NSF award.
